hints_html:
The mean is the same as the average or expected value. Which of the given probability distributions has the smallest average value? You should be able to tell just by looking at the graphs.

Variance is a measure of a measure of the “spread” of the distribution. A large variance means that we would typically expect to measure values that are far away from the mean.

The standard deviation is the square root of the variance. Hence, it is also a measure of the “spread” of the distribution. A small standard deviation means that we’d typically expect to measure values close to the mean.

4. The median is the value \(x\) for which \(P(X\leq x)=P(X>x) =\frac12.\) What does symmetry tell you about the mean and median in the last two distributions? To compare the first two, compute the median and mean in the simple case where \(a=0\) and \(b=1.\)

What is the total area under the graph of a probability distribution function?
hints_latex:
The mean is the same as the average or expected value. Which of the
given probability distributions has the smallest average value? You
should be able to tell just by looking at the graphs.

Variance is a measure of a measure of the ``spread'' of the
distribution. A large variance means that we would typically expect to
measure values that are far away from the mean.

The standard deviation is the square root of the variance. Hence, it is
also a measure of the ``spread'' of the distribution. A small standard
deviation means that we'd typically expect to measure values close to
the mean.

4. The median is the value $x$ for which $P(X\leq x)=P(X>x) =\frac12.$
What does symmetry tell you about the mean and median in the last two
distributions? To compare the first two, compute the median and mean in
the simple case where $a=0$ and $b=1.$

What is the total area under the graph of a probability distribution
function?
hints_raw:
The mean is the same as the average or expected value.  Which of the given probability distributions has the smallest average value?  You should be able to tell just by looking at the graphs.
Variance is a measure of a measure of the "spread" of the distribution.  A large variance means that we would typically expect to measure values that are far away from the mean.
The standard deviation is the square root of the variance.  Hence, it is also a measure of the "spread" of the distribution.  A small standard deviation means that we'd typically expect to measure values close to the mean.
4. The median is the value <math> x</math> for which <math>P(X\leq x)=P(X>x) =\frac12.</math>    What does symmetry tell you about the mean and median in the last two distributions?   To compare the first two, compute the median and mean in the simple case where <math> a=0</math> and <math> b=1.</math>
What is the total area under the graph of a probability distribution function?
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
The first 3 can easily be deduced just by looking at the pictures.

1. The pdf with the smallest mean is (1).

2. The pdf with the largest variance is (4).

3. The pdf with the smallest standard deviation is (3).

4. The pdf with median larger than the mean is (2).

By symmetry, both graphs (3) and (4) have the same mean and median. To decide between (1) and (2), we can compute the mean and median directly for (2). We can do this in the simple case where \(a=0\) and \(b=1\). Then \(p(x)=Cx\) for some constant \(C\). Since \(1=\int_0^1 p(x)\, dx = C \int_0^1 x\, dx = \frac{C}{2}\), \(C=2.\) The mean is then \(\int_0^1 x p(x)\, dx = 2\int_0^1 x^2\, dx = \frac23.\) The median \(m\) is determined by \(\frac12=\int_0^m p(x)\, dx = \int_0^m 2x\, dx = m^2\), hence, \(m = \frac1{\sqrt{2}},\) which is larger than \(\frac23.\)

5. The total area under the graph must be 1. Note that the area of a triangle is equal to half of its base length times its height; both triangles have the same area, with base length \(\frac{b-a}2\) and height \(y\). Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} 1=2\cdot\frac12\left(\frac{b-a}2\right) y = \frac12(b-a) y,\end{aligned}\]

where \(y\) is the maximal probability density.

Hence,

\[\begin{aligned} y = \frac{2}{b-a}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
The first 3 can easily be deduced just by looking at the pictures.

1. The pdf with the smallest mean is (1).

2. The pdf with the largest variance is (4).

3. The pdf with the smallest standard deviation is (3).

4. The pdf with median larger than the mean is (2).

By symmetry, both graphs (3) and (4) have the same mean and median. To
decide between (1) and (2), we can compute the mean and median directly
for (2). We can do this in the simple case where $a=0$ and $b=1$. Then
$p(x)=Cx$ for some constant $C$. Since
$1=\int_0^1 p(x)\, dx = C \int_0^1 x\, dx = \frac{C}{2}$, $C=2.$ The
mean is then $\int_0^1 x p(x)\, dx = 2\int_0^1 x^2\, dx  = \frac23.$ The
median $m$ is determined by
$\frac12=\int_0^m p(x)\, dx =  \int_0^m 2x\, dx = m^2$, hence,
$m = \frac1{\sqrt{2}},$ which is larger than $\frac23.$

5. The total area under the graph must be 1. Note that the area of a
triangle is equal to half of its base length times its height; both
triangles have the same area, with base length $\frac{b-a}2$ and height
$y$. Therefore,

\begin{align*}
1=2\cdot\frac12\left(\frac{b-a}2\right) y = \frac12(b-a) y,
\end{align*}

where $y$ is the maximal probability density.

Hence,

\begin{align*}
y = \frac{2}{b-a}.
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
The first 3 can easily be deduced just by looking at the pictures.

1. The pdf with the smallest mean is (1).

2. The pdf with the largest variance is (4).

3. The pdf with the smallest standard deviation is (3).

4.  The pdf with median larger than the mean is (2).

By symmetry, both graphs (3) and (4) have the same mean and median.  To decide between (1) and (2), we can compute the mean and median directly for (2).  We can do this in the simple case where <math> a=0</math> and <math>b=1 </math>.  Then <math> p(x)=Cx</math>  for some constant <math>C </math>.  Since <math> 1=\int_0^1 p(x)\, dx = C \int_0^1 x\, dx = \frac{C}{2}</math>, <math> C=2.</math>   The mean is then <math>\int_0^1 x p(x)\, dx = 2\int_0^1 x^2\, dx  = \frac23.</math> The median <math> m</math>  is determined by <math>\frac12=\int_0^m p(x)\, dx =  \int_0^m 2x\, dx = m^2</math>, hence, <math>m = \frac1{\sqrt{2}}, </math> which is larger than <math> \frac23.</math> 

5. The total area under the graph must be 1.  Note that the area of a triangle is equal to half of its base length times its height; both triangles have the same area, with base length <math>\frac{b-a}2</math> and height <math>y</math>. Therefore,

:<math> \begin{align}
1=2\cdot\frac12\left(\frac{b-a}2\right) y = \frac12(b-a) y,
\end{align}</math>

where <math>y</math> is the maximal probability density.

Hence, 

:<math> y = \frac{2}{b-a}.</math>
statement_html:
Consider the following four probability density functions (pdf):

[c]@ll@ i. & Which pdf has the smallest mean?
ii. & Which pdf has the largest variance?
iii. & Which pdf has the smallest standard deviation?
iv. & Which pdf has median larger than mean?
v. & Find the maximal probability density in (4).
(Note: the peaks at a and b are of equal heights.)
